title: Who ... ?
header: Who did say that indigenous are different people?

value.text: Considering people different it is something common in our history, in some cases we reach the level of creating an artificial hierarchy, considering a group of people inferior, but is there logic behind these actions? Did the European people consider the Indigenous were inferior?

The differentiation in Eurasia history

In this research the focus are people that had control or lived in the Iberia peninsula before they reached Abya Yala (Porto-Gonçalves, Carlos Walter, pp. 39-43)/America, because independent of the fact the Viking arrived before them (Sanders, Ralph, 2021, 7,8), they did not live for a long period of time in Abya Yala/América, and probably they also were kept away by Indigenous (McGhee, Robert, 1984).

The Greco-Roman people classified everybody living outside their borders as "barbarian", this is a generic word that "tends to transform the neighbors of the Roman Empire into a collectivity" (Walter, Goffart, 1981, pp. 277-278) and it is also a word that excludes people, like Suzanne Devallet cites (Devallet, Suzanne). This understanding apparently was kept in next centuries, but this is not the unique vision to exclude people that had influence on Iberia people.

It is also possible to find an exclusion understanding among Arab sources like Ibn Khaldūn's work (Rosenthal, Franz, 1958). When he describes the Negro people of Lamlam, that, according to his own words, were invaded and enslaved (Rosenthal, Franz, 1958, pp. 118-119), he also talks about another group of Homo sapiens living beyond them to the South:

  • "Beyond them to the south, there is no civilization in the proper sense. There are only humans that are closer to dumb animals than to rational beings. They live in thickets and caves and eat herbs and unprepared grain. They frequently eat each other. They cannot be considered human beings."

. Both people are treated as humans, but it is created an artificial distance between them, a "rational" group and another near to "irrational animals".

There is almost one millennium difference between the Roman Empire falls and Ibn Khaldūn's work, but we have similarity between the Roman people trying to be far from barbarians (Devallet, Suzanne, 2008, pp. 112) and the Arab vision to differentiate the Sub-Sahara people from areas where Arab culture were spread (Rosenthal, Franz, 1958, pp. 119).

The differentiation understanding was present in Eurasia for centuries against near people that they know, so it would not be different when they meet the unknown.

Meeting the unknown

There is documentation describing that in the whole Abya Yala/America continent the colonizers did not treat well the Indigenous, but on this page it is described only two histories that arrived in our days thanks to description given by Franciscans in Yucatán-MX and Jesuits in the old Captany of São Vicente - BR.

The colonizers action in Yucatán, where Diego de Landa stood out, against Indigenous are described by different research. Among the highlighted atrocities, it is possible to list:

  • Use of Torture (Timmer, David E., 1997, pp. 477-478).
  • Destruction of ancient Mayas' text (Timmer, David E., 1997, pp. 479-480) burning them (Segrest, Colt, 2018, pp. 32-36).
What were the reason for doing these atrocities? David E. Timmer explains that actions were taken because colonizers had an apocalyptic understanding (Timmer, David E., 1997, pp. 485-488), while Colt Segrets reports that "idolatry", according to Christian perspective, and he also cites Diego Muñoz Camargo's letter citing inferiority "hay indios tan simples y de tan poco entendimiento, que se pueden comparar con animales irracionales" (Segrest, Colt, 2018, pp. 44), this understanding is analogous to Ibn Khaldūn (Devallet, Suzanne, 2008, pp. 118-119).

Except for the fact that there was no documentation burning reported, it is also possible to observe in the ancient Capitany of São Vicente had an analogous understanding by Portuguese colonizers. The understanding of superiority, it is not explicitly written, but it was not hidden by Saint José de Anchieta, that described Tibiriçá as a person with "tanta madureza que não parecia homem do Brasil." (Anchieta, José de, Santo, 1933, pp. 187). This superiority understanding would simplify the massacre against the Indigenous grouped as "confederação dos Tamoios" (Perrone-Moisés, Beatriz, and Sztutman, Renato, 2010), here, it is not given details about these Indigenous, because the people are already described in the genealogical section.

Conclusion

In the past, there was conclusion of people's superiority based either because they considered themselves "a different society" (Devallet, Suzanne, 2008, pp. 112), or to simplify a conquest (Corrêa, Fernanda M., 2016, pp. 80,81). When we take a look in history books it is possible to be confused thinking that this is not happening nowadays, but this is a reality that unfortunately did not change, an example of this is the social concept of "race" that does not have basis from biological science, but this is not a consensus, like Rose M. Brewer shows in her work (Brewer, R.,2006). The race concept is visible through a structural racism that does not allow people to improve their lives (de Almeida, Silvio Luiz, 2018), and we still have people trying to do the indigenous inferior to explore their territory is also alive in these first years of the 21st century (Urzedo, Danilo, and Pratichi Chatterjee, 2021). Considering that this cycle of superiority and inferiority never ends, I am finishing this text with some questions to bring reflection:

  • Do you have difficult assuming that everybody is equal, only having different preferences?
  • Why do you want to be superior to others?
  • Why is your vision correct while others are wrong?
  • Is there any fear in the present or in an uncertain future that forces you to classify your opinion correct instead of other opinion?
